1.brief: properly, a pithy maxim, usually of metaphorical nature; hence, a simile (as an adage, poem, discourse)
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
probably to brighten up, i.e. (figuratively) be (causatively, make) blithe or gleesome
father, in a literal and immediate, or figurative and remote application
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
properly, fat, i.e. (figuratively) stupid or silly
a mother (as the bond of the family); in a wide sense (both literally and figuratively (like father))

2.brief: not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
properly, to ascend; figuratively, to be valuable (objectively; useful, subjectively; benefited)
rightness (abstractly), subjectively (rectitude), objectively (justice), morally (virtue) or figuratively (prosperity)
to snatch away, whether in a good or a bad sense
death (natural or violent); concretely, the dead, their place or state (hades); figuratively, pestilence, ruin

Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)
by implication, of falling); desire; also ruin
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person

the hollow hand or palm (so of the paw of an animal, of the sole, and even of the bowl of a dish or sling, the handle of a bolt, the leaves of a palm-tree); figuratively, power
a hand (the open one (indicating power, means, direction, etc.),
properly, incised or (active) incisive; hence (as noun masculine or feminine) a trench (as dug), gold (as mined), a threshing-sledge (having sharp teeth); (figuratively) determination; also eager
properly, to accumulate; chiefly (specifically) to grow (causatively, make) rich

5.brief: harvest (as the crop), whether the product (grain or fruit) or the (dry) season
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
to be (causatively, make or act) circumspect and hence, intelligent
to stun, i.e. stupefy (with sleep or death)
severed, i.e. harvest (as reaped), the crop, the time, the reaper, or figuratively; also a limb (of a tree, or simply foliage)
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
properly, to pale, i.e. by implication to be ashamed; also (by implication) to be disappointed or delayed

6.brief: the head (as most easily shaken), whether literal or figurative (in many applications, of place, time, rank, itc.)
the mouth (as the means of blowing), whether literal or figurative (particularly speech); specifically edge, portion or side; adverbially (with preposition) according to

violence; by implication, wrong; by meton. unjust gain

an appellation, as amark or memorial of individuality; by implication honor, authority, character
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person

to take (in the widest variety of applications)
a command, whether human or divine (collectively, the Law)
the lip (as a natural boundary); by implication, language; by analogy, a margin (of a vessel, water, cloth, etc.)

to walk (literally or figuratively); causatively, to carry (in various senses)

a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb
